18/n: Through all this, one thing that stood out was the generosity of strangers. Of people on social media who verified leads for us. Of total strangers who offered to ferry cylinders. Of people who helped us find a hospital bed.

9/n: When we got to the hospital, we were told that we only have the bed for 2 hours, it was pre-booked by someone and we needed to find an alternate: and that too an ICU bed, since my uncle was deteriorating.

7/n: It's when this doc broke down on the phone did I realise how dire the situation is. He told us straight off that his own family is lying in the lobby and ward of his hospital. He said there aren't enough resources.

6/n: For hours, and after countless calls, we got nothing. My uncle's oxygen dipped to 71. We got a cylinder at home and gave him oxygen. We called someone who was the head doc of a hospital in Vaishali, Gzb.

5/n: When his oxygen started dipping below 92, we proned him, and started making the calls for a hospital bed. We knew beds were scarce in Delhi, so we didn't waste any time in calling everyone we knew. This is when our real nightmare started.

4/n: My uncle caught Covid on one of his hospital visits for another treatment. We isolated him, got him consultations, and kept taking advice and meds given by professionals. We went by the rulebook.

6/n: For hours, and after countless calls, we got nothing. My uncle's oxygen dipped to 71. We got a cylinder at home and gave him oxygen. We called someone who was the head doc of a hospital in Vaishali, Gzb.

5/n: When his oxygen started dipping below 92, we proned him, and started making the calls for a hospital bed. We knew beds were scarce in Delhi, so we didn't waste any time in calling everyone we knew. This is when our real nightmare started.

(10/n) #8. Talk to your local clinic about getting a nurse to set up the oxygen cylinder at home. Once you get this shipped home and started, do keep your doc updated  on any change in the levels.  #COVID19 #COVID19India #CovidResources #OxygenShortage #OxygenCylinders #Corona

(9/n) #Oxygen cylinders typically last 7-12 hrs. Unlike oxygen concentrators, does not need electricity so no fear of power cuts. Can be refilled.   Most providers are charging around 8K-10K as refundable deposit + 1.5K to 3K per refill. The regulator costs around 2K-5K. All INR

(8/n) #7. Once you are able to get an oxygen cylinder, find out whether it comes with a regulator and an Allen key (needed to unlock cylinder and start flow).   Most don't. If no, then source it separately from pharmacies or medical equipment suppliers (Google this and call them)  https://t.co/dEBCtOMkt2

(7/n) #6. While you're making calls for #oxygen cylinders/concentrator, do also call your doctor with an update on levels and general condition + seeking advice on new medication.   Get the meds sourced and the home treatment started asap.

(5/n) #4. While you're trying to source #oxygen, make sure the patient practices proning.   With rampant #OxygenShortage, the wait for a cylinder of concentrator is long but use the time to ensure the patient sleeps in prone position as it definitely helps improve O2 flow.  https://t.co/Ji5zrEWAAi

(3/n) #2. The wait for an oxygen bed will be long. So after booking a bed, focus on getting an #oxygencylinder to use at home immediately & also cos most hospitals want you to bring your own.   You'll have to make 100s of calls, so get help from friends & colleagues & divvy it up

(1/n) The past 2 wks have been harrowing. But I only really understood how much more it must be for countless others when I found myself frantically trying to get an #oxygen bed for my uncle whose levels had fallen to 85  I hope what I learnt helps someone. Anyone #OxygenShortage

3.Oxygenated beds: For mild disease, or those unable to cope at home. Guest houses, hotels can be used with oxygen concentrators and basic nursing and doctor oversight. These facilities will free up hospital beds for the very sick.

Add one proton to Nitrogen (atomic number - 7) and it becomes Oxygen (atomic number - 8).  Simple hai! Thanks Yogi ji üôè  https://t.co/b6xJAB2yV9

It's simple: Take "Nitr" from Nitrogen, insert it into this machine:  "Idhar se aalo daalo udhar se sona niklega"  Get it converted to "xy"  Now add it to the previous one after "o". Simple. Chemical equation:  Nitrogen - nitr + xy = Oxygen
